g.text: In setting up applied functions as
in Example 5, it may be useful to review
the principles of problem solving as
know— amplitudes and patterns — can be seen easily from the graph. (The same is
true for the patterns seen in electrocardiograms of heart patients and polygraphs for
±n the next example we sketch the graph of a function that is deIned verbally.
When you turn on a hot-water faucet, the temperature
depends on how long the water has been running. Draw a rough graph of
that has elapsed since the faucet was turned on.
The initial temperature of the running water is close to room temperature
because the water has been sitting in the pipes. When the water from the hot-water tank
the temperature of the heated water in the tank. When the tank is drained,
to the temperature of the water supply. This enables us to make the rough sketch of
±n the following example we start with a verbal description of a function in a physical
situation and obtain an explicit algebraic formula. The ability to do this is a useful skill
in solving calculus problems that ask for the maximum or minimum values of quantities.
A rectangular storage container with an open top has a volume of
. The length of its base is twice its width. Material for the base costs $10 per
square meter; material for the sides costs $6 per square meter. Express the cost of mate-
rials as a function of the width of the base.
We draw a diagram as in Figure 12 and introduce notation by letting
be the width and length of the base, respectively, and
The area of the base is
, so the cost, in dollars, of the material for the
. Two of the sides have area
and the other two have area 2
cost of the material for the sides is 6
and we do so by using
the fact that the volume is 10 m
Substituting this into the expression for
Find the domain of each function.
